channel.title: Reflection Buddy
channel.description:
Inspired by [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,299985.0.html]the bank's idea[/url]. I wanted to create a 'reflection explorer' that worked on all objects (not just runescape) and also on instance variables (and not just static ones).
[img]http://www.moparisthebest.com/images/reflectionbuddy.png[/img]
The awesome GUI was created with the help of netbeans 6.1, which the bank introduced me to. I have to say it is the best GUI builder I have ever used, and best of all it uses components in the standard library.
You can run the test class (Test1.java) which sends in an instance of Test1 to ReflectionBuddy, or you can send in any object you want (like runescape's client) to see and edit all of it's variables.
offtopic: If you want to use this on runescape without writing anything, check out the latest SVN of [url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/cherokeeengine/]Cherokee[/url], put this in there and run a script sending in the client. I'll commit this to the repo shortly.
Features:
[ul][li]Works on any object[/li] [li]Allows you to give an alternate name for variables[/li] [li]Can save and load the alternate names to a properties file, which you can load into another program if you like[/li] [li]Can remove variables for better readability[/li] [li]Can change the value of all primitive types or String variables[/li] [li]Can display 1 dimensional arrays of all types (give ideas to support n-dimensional arrays)[/li] [li]Can reload the main object any time with a click[/li][/ul]
I would like to have more ideas on what to improve or add into this. Also give me clean ideas on supporting arrays with more dimensions than 1.
Any comments or constructive criticisms welcome.

item.title: Reflection Buddy
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:1, topic:230880”][…]
Also give me clean ideas on supporting arrays with more dimensions than 1.
[…][/quote]

Well, I haven’t actually looked at this program or it’s source, but I’ll go ahead and voice my idea.

For multidimensional arrays, why not just create a two-column table with x rows (x being the amount of index’s, or arrays, in that multidimensional array). Though I think I’m thinking of the wrong concept when speaking of multidimensional arrays… (array[2][3] would mean the value of the third array’s fourth index, correct?)

So after that, you can simply use your “Show Arrays” method/technique to display the array chosen after highlighting a row in that table. So if I highlighted row seven, it would display the eighth array (as indexing starts at zero).

Yes/no?

EDIT:
Disregard this comment, I was focusing on two-dimensional arrays and two-dimensional arrays only.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Buddy
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:8, topic:230880”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=304000.msg2438967#msg2438967 date=1221359187]

The way you handle your nonstatic fields will result in errors if the no-arg constructor does not exist or is not visible in the class you are looking at.

Constructors have nothing to do with it, this program doesn’t instantiate any new objects, it just reflects on the ones that are already there. If you don’t understand say so and I’ll try to explain it some other way.
[/quote]So in other words, you are using a static reference to the class in question as the argument, over creating a new instance?[/quote]

No, you send in the object you want to reflect on (such as the main class ‘client’ from runescape), then this program grabs all fields from that object (static and instance), displays the values of all classes in the standard library (like int, String, BigInteger etc), and recurses on fields that aren’t in the standard library (in the case of the runescape client, all of the other runescape classes) displaying all of thier values and so on. Does this make sense?

You might understand better if you run the included Test1 class, which reflects on Test1 so you can see what it does.

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Buddy
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

This took me a while to think through, but I don’t see why the following code shouldn’t work to fix your array problem:

public String getArray() {
	if (!field.getType().isArray())
		return "Not Array";
	StringBuilder ret = new StringBuilder("{");

	Object arr = getValue();

	if (arr == null)
		return "null";

	int dimensionCount = field.getType().getName().length() -
		field.getType().getName().replaceAll("[", "").length();
	if (dimensionCount < 1) // not an array
		return "null";

	return recurseDimension(arr, dimensionCount);	
}

private String recurseDimension(Object array, int dimension) {
	StringBuilder ret = new StringBuilder("{");
	int length = Array.getLength(array);
	for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {
		Object obj = Array.get(array, i);
		if (dimension != 0)
			ret.append(recurseDimension(obj, dimension - 1))
			.append(", ");
		else
			ret.append(obj.toString() + ", ");
		obj = null;
	}
	length = 0;
	return ret.toString().substring(0, ret.length() - 2) + "}";
}

Read full topic
